case_name: Jhagrakhan Collieries Pvt. Ltd. v. Respondents

facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 1968 of 1972 by special leave from the judgment and order dated 4th August 1971 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petition No. 41 of 1970.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1968 of 1972. Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 4th August 1971 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petition No. 41 of 1970- P. Malhotra, O. C. Mathur, and R. N. Mishra, for the Appellant.

facts.text: The appellants' writ petition under Articles 226 and 227 was dismissed by the Madhya Pradesh High Court on August 4, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave is directed against the judgment, dated August 4, 1971, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court whereby the apPellants Writ Petition under Articles 226 and 227 of the Constitution was dismissed.

facts.text: The appellant is Jhagrakhan Collieries Pvt. Ltd., a company incorporated under the Indian Companies Act, owning three collieries in Jhagrakhan in Surguja District of Madhya Pradesh, employing over 4,200 workmen.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the Jhagrakhan Collieries  P  Ltd., a Company incorporated under the Indian Companies Act. The Company owns three companylieries in Jhagrakhan in Surguja District of Madhya Pradesh. These companylieries employ over 4,200 workmen.

facts.text: At the relevant time, three trade unions functioned at the collieries: Madhya Pradesh Koyla Mazdoor Panchayat (Panchayat), Azad Koyla Shramik Sabha (Sabha), and Madhya Pradesh Colliery Workers Federation (Federation).

anchor.surface_text: At the relevant time there were three Trade Unions functioning at the companylieries, namely,  1  Madhya Pradesh Koyla Mazdoor Panchayat  for short, the Panchayat    2  Azad Koyla Shramik Sabha  for short, the Sabha , Madhya Pradesh Colliery Workers Federation  for short. the Federation

facts.text: According to the allegations of the Company, the Panchayat had about 75 per cent of the workers on its rolls.

anchor.surface_text: At the material time, the Panchayat, according to the allegations of the Company, had about 75 per cent of the workers on its rolls.

facts.text: The Panchayat conducted a complete strike for 57 days in March and April 1968 at the collieries.

anchor.surface_text: This Union companyducted a companyplete strike for 57 days in the months of March and April 1968 at the companylieries.

facts.text: The Central Wage Board for Coal Mining Industry recommended payment of Variable Dearness Allowance (V.D.A.) related to the cost of living index; the Company accepted these recommendations.

anchor.surface_text: The Central Wage Board for Coal Mining Industry by its award recommended payment of Variable Dearness Allowance  for short, V.D.A.  , companyrelated to the companyt of living index prevailing from time to time. The Company accepted these recommendations.

facts.text: Workers represented by various unions demanded V.D.A. at Rs. 1.47 per day with effect from April 1, 1968, while the Company was paying Rs. 1.11 per day and refused to pay more.

anchor.surface_text: The workers represented by ,he various Unions, on the basis of the Wage Boards award demanded V.D.A. at the rate of Rs. 1.47 per day with effect from April 1, 1968 while the Company was paying it at the rate of Rs. 1. 11 per day. The Company refused to pay more than Rs. 1.11 per day.

facts.text: In December 1968, the Federation, with membership of 169 workers (Respondents 4 to 173), made an application before the Central Labour Court-cum-Industrial Tribunal, Jabalpur under Section 33-C(2) of the Industrial Disputes Act for determination of V.D.A. due.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, in December 1968. the Federation, which had a membership of 169 workers  Respondents 4 to 173 herein  made an application before the Central Labour Court-cum-Industrial Tribunal Jabalpur  for short, the Labour Court  under Section 33-C 2  of the Industrial Dispute-, Act  for short the Act  for determination of the amount of V.D.A. due to the workers-

facts.text: The Company submitted its written statement on May 13, 1969, challenging the jurisdiction of the court and raising other legal objections.

anchor.surface_text: The Company submitted its written statement on May 13. 1969, challenging the jurisdiction of the companyrt and raised other legal objections.

facts.text: On October 4, 1969, the Panchayat served a notice of strike under Section 22(1) of the Act on the Company with a charter of 29 demands, threatening to strike on or after November 7, 1969.

anchor.surface_text: On October 4, 1969, the Panchayat served a numberice of strike under Section 22 1  of the Act on the Company together with a charter of 29 demands and threatened to strike on or after November 7, 1969 if their demands were number companyceded.

facts.text: Conciliation proceedings under s.22 read with s.12(1) were held by Mr. D. Sharma, Assistant Labour Commissioner, Shahdol on October 21 and 22, 1969.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon. the companynciliation Proceedings purporting to be under s. 22 read with s. 12 1  of the Act were held by Mr. D. Sharma, Assistant Labour Commissioner  C  Shahdol on the 21st and 22nd October. 1969.

facts.text: On October 22, 1969, during conciliation proceedings, the dispute relating to V.D.A. was settled.

anchor.surface_text: In the companyrse of these companyciliation proceedings on October 22, 1969, besides other matters. the dispute relating to V.D.A. was settled.

facts.text: On October 22, 1969, Mr. Sharma sent a report with a copy of the settlement to the Government as required by Section 12(3).

anchor.surface_text: On October 22, 1969, the Assistant Labour Commissioner  Mr. Sharma  sent a report together with a companyy of the settlement to the Government, as required by Section 12 3  of the Act.

facts.text: On November 5, 1969, the Company filed a supplementary statement submitting that the s.33C(2) application had become infructuous due to the settlement.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequent to the signing of this companyciliation agreement, dated October 22, 1969. the Company filed a supplementary statement on November 5, 1969, submitting that in view of the said settlement, the application under s. 33C 2  of the Act filed by the Federation, had become infructuous.

facts.text: Labour Court by order dated December 20, 1969 framed additional issue: whether the claim stands settled by settlement dated 22-10-1969.

anchor.surface_text: The Labour Court by its order, dated December 20, 1969 framed this additional issue Whether the claim stands settled by reason of settlement dated 22-10-1969, if any.

facts.text: Workers raised objections that the settlement was not enforceable as it was not brought about in proceedings before a duly appointed Conciliation Officer.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the workers several objections were raised to the enforceability of. this settlement, Their ultimate stand was that the settlement was number in accordance with the provisions of the Act, inasmuch as it had number been brought about in proceedings before a duly appointed Conciliation Officer.

facts.text: Labour Court held as preliminary issue that Shri Sharma was not a duly appointed Conciliation Officer on the date of settlement, so it did not end the dispute.

anchor.surface_text: The Labour Court tried this issue as a preliminary issue. It held that Shri Sharma was number a duly appointed Conciliation Officer on the date on which the settlement was arrived at, and companysequently, it did number put an end to the dispute pending before the Labour Court.

facts.text: Company filed writ petition under Articles 226 and 227 to impugn Labour Court order, which was dismissed by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: To impugn this order of the Labour Court, the Company through its agent and Mining Engineer filed a Writ Petition under Article 226 and 227 of the Constitution, which as stated before, was dismissed by the High Court.

facts.text: High Court finding that settlement was not arrived at in course of conciliation proceedings stands unassailed.

anchor.surface_text: Since the finding of the High Court to the effect that the settlement between the Panchayat and the management cannot be deemed to be settlement arrived at in the companyrse of companyciliation proceedings under the Act, number stands unassailed.

facts.text: Respondents 4 to 173 and members of Sabha were not parties or signatories to the October 22, 1969 settlement.

anchor.surface_text: The question remains Can it be enforced against these Respondents by virtue of sub-section  1  of the Section ? This further narrows down into the issue Were these respondents parties and signatories to the agreement between the management and the Panchayat ? The answer to this question is undoubtedly in the negative.

facts.text: Company contended that 99% of workers accepted the settlement by drawing D.A. thereunder.

anchor.surface_text: Even Mr. Malhotra has companyceded that at the time when the settlement was arrived at on October 22, 1969, these respondents and the members of the Sabha. were number Parties to it. But his argument is that subsequently by drawing D.A. in accordance with the settlement, 99 of the workers have accepted the settlement

facts.text: Court held that even if 99% workers accepted by conduct, it does not make the agreement a settlement under the Act binding on non-parties.

anchor.surface_text: As rightly pointed out by Mr. Ramamurthy, learned Counsel for the Respondents an implied agreement by acquiescence, or companyduct such as acceptance of a benefit under an agreement in which the worker acquiescing or accepting the benefit was number a party being outside the purview of the Act, is number binding on such a worker

facts.text: Labour Court refused permission to Company to lead evidence on 99% acceptance, but no prejudice caused as issue was legal.

anchor.surface_text: The refusal of the Labour Court to allow the appellant to lead evidence at this stage, has number caused any prejudice to the appellant. The issue decided as a preliminary issue involved a question of law which companyld be decided on the, basis of material on record.

anchor.surface_text: a  Assuming that the settlement in question was number a settlement in the companyrse of companyciliation proceedings and binding under s. 18 3  on the Act, it was still a settlement binding on the workman, including respondents 4 to 173 herein, when 99 per cent of the total workmen had accepted the terms of the settlement, including V.D.A.

arguments.claim: Settlement qualifies as second kind under s.2(p): written agreement otherwise than conciliation, signed prescribed manner, copy sent to officer

anchor.surface_text: Section 2 p  of the Act defines settlement to mean- a settlement arrived at in the course of conciliation proceedings and includes a written agreement between the employer and workmen arrived at otherwise than in the course of conciliation proceeding where such agreement has been signed by the parties thereto in such manner as may be prescribed and a copy thereof has been sent to  an officer authorised in this behalf by  the appropriate Government and the conciliation officer.

arguments.claim: s.18(3) binds all workmen only for conciliation settlements; s.18(1) binds only parties for other settlements; embodies collective bargaining

anchor.surface_text: 18 1  A settlement arrived at by agreement between the employer and workmen otherwise than in the course of conciliation proceedings shall be binding on the parties to the agreement. ... A settlement arrived at in the course of conciliation proceedings under this Act ... shall be binding on- ... In extending the operation of such a settlement beyond the parties thereto, sub-section  3  of the Section departs from the ordinary law of contract and gives effect to the principle of collective bargaining.

arguments.claim: Amalgamated Coffee Estates distinguishable as arose under s.10(1) not s.33C(2); broader jurisdiction there

anchor.surface_text: There the appeals arose, out of an award of the Special Industrial Tribunal for plantations in a dispute between 228 coffee, tea and rubber estates in South India and their employees referred to it under S. 10 1  whereas the instant appeal arises out of proceedings under S. 33-C 2  for the recovery

arguments.claim: s.33C(2) is execution-like for money claims based on award/settlement; not for adjudicating disputes like s.10(1)

anchor.surface_text: the instant appeal arises out of proceedings under S. 33-C 2  for the recovery of money on the basis of the Wage Boards award and the dispute, if any, is about the computation of V.D.A. in implementation of that award. The scope of S. 33-C 2  is not the same as that of s. 10 1  of the Act.

holdings.text: The finding of the High Court that the settlement between the Panchayat and the management cannot be deemed to be a settlement arrived at in the course of conciliation proceedings under the Act stands unassailed.

anchor.surface_text: Since the finding of the High Court to the effect that the settlement between the Panchayat and the management cannot be deemed to be settlement arrived at in the course of conciliation proceedings under the Act, number stands unassailed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner withdrew challenge to lower courts' interpretation of Section 4; High Court finding accepted without decision.

holdings.text: A settlement not arrived at in the course of conciliation proceedings cannot be invoked under Section 18(3) to bind non-parties like Respondents 4 to 173.

anchor.surface_text: the aforesaid sub-section  3  cannot be invoked to make it binding on Respondents 4 to 173. The question remains Can it be enforced against these Respondents by virtue of sub-section  1  of the Section ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 18(3) applies only to conciliation settlements which bind all workmen; instant settlement falls under s.18(1) limited to parties.

holdings.text: Respondents 4 to 173 were not parties or signatories to the settlement agreement between the management and the Panchayat.

anchor.surface_text: This further narrows down into the issue Were these respondents parties and signatories to the agreement between the management and the Panchayat ? The answer to this question is undoubtedly in the negative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Undisputed fact conceded by petitioner's counsel; confirmed by record.

holdings.text: An implied agreement by acquiescence or conduct, such as acceptance of a benefit under an agreement to which the worker was not a party, is not a 'settlement' under the Act and is not binding under Section 18(1) or (3).

anchor.surface_text: As rightly pointed out by Mr. Ramamurthy, learned Counsel for the Respondents an implied agreement by acquiescence, or conduct such as acceptance of a benefit under an agreement in which the worker acquiescing or accepting the benefit was number a party being outside the purview of the Act, is number binding on such a worker

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of s.2(p) and s.18 requires written signed agreement for non-conciliation settlements; implied acceptance outside statutory purview.

holdings.text: Even if 99% of workers accepted the settlement by drawing V.D.A., it does not put an end to the dispute before the Labour Court qua non-parties.

anchor.surface_text: It follows, therefore, that even if 99 of the workers have impliedly accepted the agreement arrived at on October 22, 1969, by drawing V.D.A., under it, it will number-whatever its effect under the general law-put an end to the dispute before the Labour Court

holdings.reasoning_summary: Acceptance by conduct does not transform into statutory settlement binding non-parties; Labour Court retains jurisdiction under s.33C(2).

holdings.text: The Labour Court's refusal to allow evidence of 99% acceptance caused no prejudice to the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The refusal of the Labour Court to allow the appellant to lead evidence at this stage, has number caused any prejudice to the appellant. The issue decided as a preliminary issue involved a question of law which companyld be decided on the, basis of material on record.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue was pure question of law decidable on record; even assuming fact, no impact on non-parties.

holdings.text: A settlement arrived at otherwise than in conciliation proceedings during pendency of s.33C(2) proceedings is enforceable only against parties thereto, not non-parties.

anchor.surface_text: Assuming that the Act does number inhibit the employers and the workmen from arriving at a settlement during the pendency of proceedings under s. 33-C 2  of the Act, such a settlement, number being one arrived at in the companyrse of companyciliation proceedings would be enforceable only against the parties thereto.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No statutory prohibition on settlements, but bindingness governed by s.18(1) for non-conciliation agreements.

holdings.text: Proceedings under s.33C(2) are in nature of execution for recovery of money due under award/settlement, narrower scope than adjudication under s.10(1).

anchor.surface_text: the instant appeal arises out of proceedings under S. 33-C 2  for the recovery of money on the basis of the Wage Boards award and the dispute, if any, is about the companyputation of V.D.A. in implementation of that award. The scope of S. 33-C 2  is number the same as that of s. 10 1  of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Amalgamated Coffee Estates (s.10 reference) where court had broader rehearing jurisdiction; cites East India Coal.

holdings.text: Section 2(p) contemplates two kinds of settlements: (i) in course of conciliation proceedings; (ii) written agreements otherwise, signed in prescribed manner with copy to officers.

anchor.surface_text: Section 2 p  of the Act defines settlement to mean- a settlement arrived at in the companyrse of companyciliation proceedings and includes a written agreement between the employer and workmen arrived at otherwise than in the course of conciliation proceeding where such agreement has been signed by the parties thereto in such manner as may be prescribed and a companyy thereof has been sent to  an officer authorised

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis of definition; conditions for second kind not satisfied here.

holdings.text: Section 18(3) binds all workmen in establishment for conciliation settlements, departing from contract law to effect collective bargaining; s.18(1) binds only parties for others.

anchor.surface_text: 18 1  A settlement arrived at by agreement between the employer and workmen otherwise than in the companyrse of companyciliation proceedings shall be binding on the parties to the agreement. ... In extending the operation of such a settlement beyond the parties thereto, sub-section  3  of the Section departs from the ordinary law of companytract and gives effect to the principle of companylective bargaining.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive interpretation distinguishing binding effects; embodies collective bargaining.
